scenario: Emergency medical transport coordination involves collaboration between hospitals, ambulance services, and air evacuation teams, each holding private information that could impact patient care and resource allocation.
task: Develop a comprehensive emergency transport plan that balances patient needs, resource availability, and response times. Agents must navigate competing priorities: timely patient transfers may conflict with resource limitations and facility capacities. They must strategically share information—enough to coordinate effectively while protecting sensitive patient data and operational constraints.

agents.name: Hospital Coordinator
agents.role: Manages patient intake and transfer logistics, ensuring swift access to necessary medical facilities.
responsibilities: Assess incoming patient needs and prioritize transfers.
Coordinate with ambulance services for timely dispatch.
Maintain communication with receiving facilities for capacity updates.

success_criteria.Transfer Coordination: All agents agree on a transfer protocol that optimally utilizes available resources while prioritizing patient safety.
success_criteria.Response Time Agreement: Consensus on response times that meet or exceed the operational targets set by each agency.
success_criteria.Capacity Management: Agreement on how to manage patient loads and resource allocations effectively without compromising care.

deliverable: An emergency transport coordination plan detailing patient transfer protocols, resource allocations, and response strategies.

private: Hospital capacity must not exceed 90% during peak transfers
Ambulance service must maintain at least 80% operational readiness
Air evacuation must have a backup plan for adverse weather conditions
